```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
  count()%>%
  ggplot(aes(reorder(x=Region, n), y =n, fill = Nationality2)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  coord_flip()+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = integer_breaks())+
  labs(title = "American University Men in China: Area of study", 
       subtitle = "Area of study", 
       x = NULL,
       y = "Number of curricula", 
       fill = "Nationality",
       caption = "Based on 'American University Men in China' (1936)")

fig30a <- ggplotly(p30a) 

fig30a

```

<br>
This largely reflected the high concentration of first-tier universities on the East coast (Columbia, Harvard): 
```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Region == "East coast") %>% 
  group_by(Region, State, University) %>% 
  count(sort = TRUE) 

```

<br>
In the immediate proximity of the East coast, Middle Eastern states represented the second most attractive area (31%). Many prestigious universities were also located in this area (Chicago, Michigan): 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Region == "Middle East") %>% 
  group_by(Region, State, University) %>% 
  count(sort = TRUE) 

```

<br>
Next we find the Pacific Coast (10%), represented by two major universities (California, Stanford): 
```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Region == "Pacific Coast") %>% 
  group_by(Region, State, University) %>% 
  count(sort = TRUE) 

```

<br> 
Finally, the middle West and Southeastern states accounted for less than 10% each: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Region == "Middle West") %>% 
  group_by(Region, State, University) %>% 
  count(sort = TRUE) 

```
```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Region == "Southeast") %>% 
  group_by(Region, State, University) %>% 
  count(sort = TRUE) 

```

<br>
Overall, the distribution reflected the geography of higher education in the United States at the time, which for a large part has persisted to date.  

Other regions outside the United States represented a minority. A few Chinese born overseas studied in their native region (Hawaii, Canada). Degrees obtained in China referred to honorary degrees granted by St John's University in Shanghai. A few students studied in European countries (United Kingdom, Netherlands) or in Japan before or after coming to the United States. 

## Chinese / foreign

Chinese students largely accounted for the general trend, except for the Middle West that appeared after China in the ranking (only three curricula): 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>% 
  group_by(Nationality, Region)  %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(100 * n/sum(n), 0), "%")) %>% 
  arrange(desc(n))

```

<br>

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Nationality2 == "Other") %>% 
  group_by(Region)  %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(100 * n/sum(n), 0), "%")) %>% 
  arrange(desc(n))

```
<br> 
Non-Chinese students showed a stronger attraction for the Pacific Coast (13%) and to a lesser extent, the Middle West, at the expenses of the East Coast (45%). As noticed in previous studies, racial prejudices against Chinese nationals were stronger on the Pacific Coast. The attraction of Chinese students on the East Coast also reflected more specifically the heritage of the Chinese Educational Mission (1872-1882) with its headquarters in New England (Hartford, Connecticut). 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

p30 <- auc5 %>% 
  group_by(Region, Nationality2) %>%
  count()%>%
  ggplot(aes(reorder(x=Region, n), y =n, fill = Nationality2)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()+
  facet_wrap(~Nationality2, scale = "free")+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = integer_breaks())+
  labs(title = "American University Men in China: Area of study", 
       subtitle = "Area of study", 
       x = NULL,
       y = "Number of curricula", 
       caption = "Based on 'American University Men in China' (1936)")

fig30 <- ggplotly(p30) %>% hide_legend()

fig30

```

<br>
Let's now focus on the Chinese students. Do we observe a shift from the East coast to the middle West? Did our sample population support previous studies that have emphasized a gradual shift from the East the Middle West from the 1920s onwards, due to lower cost of living and the emergence of specialized institutions (engineering, medicine) in this region (Potts, 1936)? 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc5 %>% filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>% 
  drop_na(period)%>%
  group_by(period, Region)  %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(100 * n/sum(n), 0), "%")) %>% 
  arrange(period, desc(n))

```
<br> 
During the first period, the majority of Chinese students concentrated in the Middle East area (50%) at the University of Chicago (4) and Oberlin (2). One third studied on the East coast (Yale, Columbia, Harvard) and 17% on the Pacific Coast (California, Pomona): 
```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc5 %>% filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>% 
  filter(period == "1883-1908")%>%
  group_by(period, Region, University) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(desc(n), Region)
```

<br>
The situation changed after the Boxer Indemnity Program was launched in 1909. The East Coast now represented the first destination (62%) and Middle East area came second (28%). The Eastern region (East Coast and Middle East included) clearly dominated and the Pacific Coast became less attractive (6%). 

On the Pacific coast, Columbia became the primary choice for Chinese students during this period. This reflected its privileged ties with Qinghua College established in Beijing 1909 to prepare Boxer Indemnity Fellows to study in the United States, as well as the popularity of Columbia's Teachers College for students willing to specialized in education. The high rank of Harvard and Pennsylvania perpetuated the heritage of the Chinese Educational Mission. Yale still ranked high but we also observed the emergence of specialized institutions on the East Coast (Cornell, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Massachusetts Agricultural College) or in Middle Eastern states: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc5 %>% filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>% 
  filter(period == "1909-1918")%>%
  group_by(period, Region, University) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(desc(n), Region)
```


<br>
During the last phase, we observed a shift again towards the Middle Eastern states (32%) and the Pacific Coast (9%), at the expense of the East Coast, which nonetheless continued to dominate (54%): 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc5 %>% filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>% 
  filter(period == "1919-1935")%>%
  group_by(period, Region, University) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(desc(n), Region)
```
<br>

In conclusion, Chinese students spread across a larger number of states and universities from the second period, but at the same time, the tended to clustered in the most prestigious universities in the Eastern part of the country.

# Occupations

What was their occupations? Where were they recruited after graduation? In which sector were they employed? Who was their employer? 

It is important to mention that the directory indicated the individuals' current employment only (in 1936). It did not list all the positions they had held since graduation (and even sometimes during their studies for the students who took part-time jobs to pay for their studies or those who were willing to apply their academic training on the field). As such, the directory offers just a snapshot of AUM's occupations at the time of its publication. The publication occurred at different points in the life trajectory of each individual. Their current employment therefore referred to a variety of situation, which makes it difficult to compare the individuals' respective level of achievement. Supplementing the data set with birth data (year of birth) would allow to compute their age at the time of publication and therefore better situate the current employment in their personal career. In the meantime, we will use the period of graduation as a proxy. 

Based on the information given on their employer, we devised the following classification that defines nine main sectors of activity (Sector_1) subdivided into 43 categories (Sector_2): 

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc4 %>% distinct(Sector_1, Sector_2) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  arrange(Sector_1, Sector_2)

```
Before we analyze in greater detail the sector of employment, let's create a simplified dataset containing only unique individuals with their respective occupation: 

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job <- auc4 %>% distinct(Name_eng, Name_zh, 
                             Nationality, period, 
                             Employer_main, Employer_2, 
                             Sector_1, Sector_2, 
                             Country, City)

datatable(auc_job)

```
<br>
The new list contains 432 individuals with their name and nationality, the name of their employer, the main and secondary sector of activity, the country and the city in which they worked. It also includes the period of graduation for further examining the potential effect of time on job opportunities.      


## Sector 

Let's plot the number of individuals employed in each sector of activity for each national group: 

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

p23 <- auc_job %>% 
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  drop_na(Nationality) %>%
  group_by(Sector_1, Nationality) %>%
  count()%>%
  ggplot(aes(reorder(x=Sector_1, n), y =n, fill = Sector_1)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  facet_wrap(~Nationality, nrow = 3, scale = "free_y")+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = integer_breaks())+
  labs(title = "American University Men in China: Sector of employment", 
       subtitle = "Sector of employment", 
       x = NULL,
       y = "Number of individuals", 
       caption = "Based on 'American University Men in China' (1936)")

fig23 <- ggplotly(p23) %>% hide_legend()

fig23

```

<br>
Private companies clearly dominated in the three groups. The central government in China came next among Chinese graduates, whereas their Western fellows held positions in non-profit organizations. Education was the third major post of employment for Chinese and Westerners alike. The remaining Chinese were distributed across organizations, local government and health institutions. Positions in foreign institutions in China (legations, consulates) came next among foreigners (23). We also found a dozen of Westerners who worked for the Chinese central government. The remaining Westerners were scattered across a myriad of sectors, especially hospitals, judiciary institutions, local government (provincial or municipal governments) and the military  (US Navy). Due to the small number of Japanese graduates, the pattern of their employment is not statistically significant.    

Let's analyze in greater detail the proportion of the various sectors in each national group, and conversely, the proportion of the two main national groups in each sector. In the process, we will examine a few examples for each sector.

Sector of employment in each national group:

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>% 
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  drop_na(Nationality) %>%
  group_by(Nationality, Sector_1) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(Nationality, desc(n))


```
<br> 
The table confirms that employment in private companies dominated among Chinese AUM (101 individuals, 59%). The central government ranked second (31, 18%) before educational institutions (22, 13%). Other sectors employed less than 10% of American-trained Chinese each. These findings partly supports previous studies that had shown the prevalence of teaching and positions in the central government under the Nationalist regime (Wang, 1966, 169). Our population, however, also derived from this pattern by the heavy weight of the private sector. Moreover, government service came before education, whereas this ranking was reversed in Wang's survey. The private sector represented about the same share among Westerners (86, 58%). Next we found non-profit organizations that employed 20 individuals (13%) and foreign government institutions employing 16 individuals (11%). Teaching represented only 8% (12). Other sectors remained a minority. 

Proportion of national groups in each sector:

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>%  
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  drop_na(Nationality) %>%
  group_by(Sector_1, Nationality) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(Sector_1, desc(n))


```
<br>
Chinese graduates dominated everywhere, except in foreign institutions in China (none) and non-profit organizations (31%). They were at par with Westerners in health institutions and represented a shorter majority in private companies (53%), local government (60%), and education (65%). Westerners dominated in judiciary and military institutions. 

## Occupations over time

How did AUM's occupations evolved over time, based on the graduation period? For this study, we focus on Chinese graduates: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  drop_na(period) %>%
  group_by(period, Sector_1) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(period, desc(n))


```
<br>
The three Chinese AUM who graduated before the Boxer Indemnity Program were employed in two main sectors - two worked for private companies and one worked for the national government. Since the late imperial years, the private sector had been a major outlet for the Chinese returned students. This is too small a sample for generalizing but it appears that the national government was not the primary employer for these pioneering American-trained Chinese, who more often set up their own business or worked for others'. The occupation of two individuals remained undetermined, but we know from other sources that Kuang Fuzhuo 鄺富灼 (Fong F. Sec) had long been associated with the Commercial Press (a private company in the publishing industry): 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
datatable(auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(period == "1883-1908"))
```
<br>
Professional opportunities considerably broadened and diversified for the students who graduated in the early years of the Republic. The private sector (28, 45%) and the national government (16, 26%) remained the two primary employers but as a new educational system was being set up, teaching became a new important outlet (10, individual 16%). The remaining graduates worked for non-profit organizations, especially the Young Men's Christian Association (Y.M.C.A.) (6%), hospitals (Central Hospital in Nanjing and the Orthopedic Hospital in Shanghai) and municipal governments (Shanghai Municipal Council, Municipality of Greater Shanghai) (2, 3% each). We have no information on the professional situation of 19 individuals: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
datatable(auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(period == "1909-1918")%>%
  arrange(Sector_1))
```
<br> 
The private sector became even more attractive for the students who graduated after WWI (76, 67%). Positions in the central government declined but still ranked second (14%), before education (11%). Organizations, local government and health institutions employed less than 5% each. The occupation of 41 individuals remains undocumented:  

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
datatable(auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(period == "1919-1935")%>%
  arrange(Sector_1))
```

## Subsector

The private sector, the central government and non-profit organizations are very broad categories. In which sub-fields did the AUM work more specifically? 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  drop_na(Sector_2) %>%
  group_by(Sector_1, Sector_2) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(Sector_1, desc(n))


```
<br>
Service industries dominated in the private sector. **Banking** ranked first (30%) before insurance (17%) and trade (10%). This supports previous studies that have linked the domination of American-trained experts among Chinese bankers to the development of a modern banking system patterned after Western models in Republican China (Wang, 1966, 171, Sheehan, 2021). 
The **press and the publishing** industry represented 11%. 
Despite the heavy weight of the silk and cotton industries in the Jiangsu region, **textile** enterprises employed just 6% of American University Men. Despite the boom in real estate in the early 1930s, the **building** sector represented just 2%. Despite the emphasis on technology since the late imperial years, revived during the Nanjing decade, engineers in various sectors remained a minority, which corroborates S.M. Lee's study of American-trained engineers' contribution in the first part of the directory (Lee, 1936, p. 91-106). Light industries of later emergence (movie, automobile, food) remained underdeveloped in China, even among our American-trained entrepreneurs: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
datatable(auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(Sector_1 == "Company") %>%
  group_by(Sector_2, Employer_main) %>% 
  count())
```

<br>
Among the students employed by the *government*, 70% worked for the administration, mostly in national railways companies (National Southern Railway) and special state institutions such as the Salt Revenue Administration or the Maritime Customs. Two worked in technical bureaus (Bureau of Trademark, Bureau of Foreign Trade) under the supervision of the Ministry of Industry: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(Sector_1 == "Central Government") %>%
  filter(Sector_2 == "Administration") %>% 
    group_by(Employer_main) %>% 
    count(sort = TRUE)
```
<br>
Four worked for various ministries (especially Finance and Transportation or Commmunications) and 6% held legislative positions: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(Sector_1 == "Central Government") %>%
  filter(Sector_2 == "Ministry") %>% 
    group_by(Employer_main) %>% 
    count(sort = TRUE)
```

<br>
Nine served in non-profit organizations of a transnational, religious (Y.M.C.A., China Christian Advocate) or philanthropic nature (Chinese Red Cross, China International Famine Relief Commission):  

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(Sector_1 == "Organization") %>%
    group_by(Employer_main) %>% 
    count(sort = TRUE)
```
<br> 
The AUM employed in education worked exclusively in universities (especially Jiaotong University in Shanghai), which supports the common, enduring assumption since the 1930s that foreign-educated elites were reluctant to teach in primary and middle schools especially in the interior (Ly, 1936, p.36, Wang 1966, 182-185): 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
auc_job %>% 
  filter(Nationality == "Chinese") %>%
  filter(Sector_1 == "Education") %>%
    group_by(Employer_main) %>% 
    count(sort = TRUE)
```

<br>
Sector of employment and graduation period:

If we focus on the three main sectors:

Although the private sector prevailed over all other sectors, the top employer among Chinese graduates was not a private company, but a leading educational institution - Jiaotong University. ## Workplace

Where were the AUM employed in 1936? 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>% 
  drop_na(City) %>%
  group_by(City) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))


```
<br> 
The overwhelming majority of American University Men worked in Shanghai (94%). This is hardly surprising since this the club was based in Shanghai. A few members, however, reported working outside of Shanghai. Among these outsiders, Nanjing, the capital of the Nationalist regime ranked first (10 individuals, 2%). A few others worked in the former capital Peiping (Beijing) and in important treaty ports (Hangzhou, Guangzhou) (2 each). Even fewer were those employed abroad (one in Singapore, one in California) or in secondary cities in China (Haichow, Hankow, Soochow, Tangshan). 

These findings support previous surveys that have emphasized the American-returned students' propensity to congregate in large urban centers, especially treaty ports (Wang, 1966, 162-4). Wang noticed that very few foreign-educated men lived in towns smaller than county seats. He further observed that the urbanization of foreign-trained elites was a notable departure from the imperial practice in China according to which the most cherished ambition of a successful man was to return to his native district. These changes in elite residential patterns, however, reflected not so much their cultural attraction for the Westernized, urbanized way of life but rather, the historical fact that cities in general tended to concentrate population, capital, markets and networks, and therefore, job opportunities. Our American University Men knew that it was in large urban centers, not in rural villages, that they would find the human and economic resources they needed to develop their business and the best opportunities to employ their talents. 


The distribution of workplaces among each national group is shown below: 

```{r warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

auc_job %>% 
  drop_na(City) %>%
  drop_na(Nationality) %>%
  group_by(Nationality, City) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  mutate(ptg = paste0(round(n / sum(n) * 100, 0), "%")) %>%
  arrange(Nationality, desc(n))


```
<br> 
As their Chinese fellows, foreigners also worked primarily in Shanghai (98-100%%). Only one worked in Beijing. Two were employed outside of China, in Singapore and California. Almost all Chinese worked in their native country, except for one in Singapore and one in New York. The overwhelming majority was also based in Shanghai (91%) but they were more widely scattered across China. 


How did their workplace relate to the sector of employment?

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
  ggplot(aes(reorder(x=City, n), y =n, fill = Sector_1)) +
 facet_grid(Sector_1~Nationality,  scales = "free") +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()  +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = integer_breaks())+
  labs(title = "American University Men in China: Workplace and Sector of Employment", 
       subtitle = "City", 
       x = NULL,
       y = "Number of individuals", 
       fill = "Sector",
       caption = "Based on 'American University Men in China' (1936)")

fig28 <- ggplotly(p28) %>% hide_legend()

fig28

```
<br>

Let's focus on Chinese members:

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
  drop_na(City) %>%
  drop_na(Sector_1) %>%
  filter(Nationality =="Chinese")%>%
  group_by(Sector_1, City)%>%
  count()%>%
  ggplot(aes(reorder(x=City, n), y =n, fill = Sector_1)) +
 facet_wrap(~Sector_1,  scales = "free") +
```

Except for local government and educational institutions, all employers, whatever their nature, were based in either Shanghai or Nanjing. The private sector was the only sector that offered opportunities to work abroad, especially in the United States (New York) and Singapore. 


# Concluding remarks

While the first alumni were American expatriates, Chinese students in the United States rose after the Boxer Indemnity Scholarship was established in 1909 and boomed after WWI. As a result, Chinese members rapidly outnumbered their foreign fellows. 

Chinese graduates generally showed a higher level of qualification than their foreign counterparts. Most of them earned at least two degrees, some of them up to three or four. Consequently, the proportion of masters and doctorates was higher among Chinese students. Based on this data, therefore, we are led to nuance previous assumptions about the allegedly low academic standards of the Chinese students abroad (Wang, 1966, 165-8).

Chinese students were more inclined towards professional and technical fields, especially business, medicine and engineering, whereas the humanities and liberal arts dominated among Western graduates. This supports the general emphasis on technology and “practical” learning since the late imperial years and particularly during the Nanjing decade, as highlighted in previous studies (Wang, 1966, 168-174; Meng, 1931, 8). Chinese members of the American University Club, however, enjoyed a large degree of free choice, especially in comparison to their fellow countrymen in Japan or Europe, who were placed under stricter supervision (Wang, 1966:). In contrast to other surveys, the proportion of educators and political sciences remained comparatively low in our population, even among those who graduated during the founding period of the Republic (1911-9). This, however, may reflect differences in the method used for compiling information. (We may conjecture, for instance, that degrees in education were included in the humanities and those in political sciences were confounded with law). Notwithstanding methodological inconsistencies, the AUM's educational choices reflected the "laissez-faire" policy that prevailed in the early years of the Republic (Wang, 1966, 104, 112). It was not until 1928, in effect, that the government emphasized technology and defined quotas in education, applied sciences and other technical disciplines for the students who benefited from a government scholarship. Moreover, we suspect that American University Men included a large number of self-supporting students (as opposed to those directly sponsored by the government) who were freer to chose their field of study. Further research is needed to determine the American University Men's source of funding and how it related to their educational choice.

Regarding their occupations, the private sector was the primary employer for both groups - Chinese and Westerners. Among private companies, the banking sector clearly dominated. The central government was the second largest employer for Chinese members. Teaching also developed as a major outlet for this group of returned students during the Republic. Besides private companies, foreign graduates worked in transnational organizations and foreign institutions in China.

Because the club was based in Shanghai, most members worked in this city. Outside of Shanghai, Nanjing was the second major workplace, reflecting the heavy weight of government officials among American University Men. Few Chinese returned students worked outside of their country/ abroad. They were more widely scattered across China than Westerners, who tended to congregate in treaty ports.

Where and when were they born? Unfortunately, the directory did not mention the place and date of birth. While the year of birth can generally be inferred from the year of graduation, further research is needed to document their place of birth (province, ancestry). The very fact the directory did not provide such information is revealing. As previous studies have pointed out, the returned students emphasized their national or professional identity, rather than their native place origins and ancestry, which represented a major departure from the previous imperial elites (Wang, 1966, 156-164).    
In the next essays, we will deepen these findings through a combination of multivariate, geospatial, network and sequence analyses, aimed at correlating the various attributes and patterns we have examined separately so far. 

# Appendix

**Method for selecting each individual's highest degrees** 

In order to perform multiple correspondence analysis (MCA) and for other interpretation such as the area of specialization, it is useful to have a list of unique individuals with the last degrees they obtained. For this purpose, we start from the dataset "highest" that we produced for analyzing individual curricula and the length of study. The resulting list still contained 23 individuals who obtained 2 (or 3) degrees during the last year of their studies. Based on this list, we apply the following guidelines for determining the highest degree: 

  * Select the highest level (doctorate rather than master, master rather than bachelor)
  * Select the most specialized (tropical medicine rather than medicine)
  * In case the individual earned two specialized degrees, we retain the degree that was closer to his current position in 1936 (in other words, we emphasize matching over mismatching between training and employment)
  * In case of undetermined PhD (and more generally, in cases when the field of the highest level was undetermined), we retain doctorates (the highest level) as the highest level and we add the specialization of the immediately lower degree. 
  * In cases of degrees obtained outside the United States, select the last degree granted by an American university.
